greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of Dyck paths of semilength n having k ascents of length 2.
comment: T(n,k) is the number of Łukasiewicz paths of length n having k steps (1,1). A Łukasiewicz path of length n is a path in the first quadrant from (0,0) to (n,0) using rise steps (1,k) for any positive integer k, level steps (1,0) and fall steps (1,-1) (see R. P. Stanley, Enumerative Combinatorics, Vol. 2, Cambridge Univ. Press, Cambridge, 1999, p. 223, Exercise 6.19w; the integers are the slopes of the steps). Example: T(3,0)=2 because we have HHH and U(2)DD, where H=(1,0), U(2)=(1,2) and D=(1,-1). Row n has 1+floor(n/2) terms. Row sums yield the Catalan numbers (A000108). T(2n,n)=A000108(n). Column 0 is A102403
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..200, flattened
Index entries for sequences related to Łukasiewicz
example: T(4,2) = 2 because we have UUDDUUDD and UUDUUDDD, where U=(1,1) and D=(1,-1).
mathematica: CoefficientList[#, t]& /@ Take[CoefficientList[G[t, z], z], m] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 05 2019 *)
